channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russian Blockade Heightens Fears of Global Grain Shortage
item.description: The World Food Program warned that the disruption could be disastrous for the poorest parts of the world. Russia said that nearly 1,000 fighters had surrendered at the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salvaging items on Tuesday from an apartment complex in Chernihiv that was hit by a Russian airstrike in March.

item.title: How a Group of Female Independents Aims to Revive Australian Democracy
item.description: A community-driven movement has recruited around 25 candidates, most of them successful women preaching pragmatic reform. They could shape the balance of power after Saturday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Stephanie Simcox for The New York Times
item.media:description: Allegra Spender, an independent candidate for the Australian federal Parliament, is part of a movement aiming to save Australian democracy from the creep of corruption, right-wing populism and misogyny.

item.title: An Indian State Banned Alcohol. The Drinking Moved to Nearby Nepal.
item.description: The ban in Bihar State, championed by local women, was aimed at tackling alcoholism and domestic violence. But a drinking scene has sprung up across the border in Nepal.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharing food and drinks at a bar in Mahottari, Nepal, just across the border with India.

item.title: The 17th-Century English Judge Behind Abortion and Rape Rulings Today
item.description: Both in India and in the Roe v. Wade draft ruling roiling the United States, Lord Matthew Hale — an English judge who wrote that women were contractually obligated to husbands — still looms large.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Universal History Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The 17th-century English jurist Lord Matthew Hale was cited in a recent Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade.

item.title: China-Style Covid Lockdowns Risk Deepening North Korean Crisis
item.description: As infections spread quickly, outside experts are warning that the country’s desire to mimic Beijing’s playbook could worsen a coming disaster.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed North Korean leader Kim Jong-un attending a meeting on anti-virus strategies in Pyongyang, North Korea last week.

item.title: In Ukraine, Gruesome Injuries and Not Enough Doctors to Treat Them
item.description: Operating with skeleton crews, doctors and nurses race to save limbs, and lives. It’s a grim routine for medical personnel often working around the clock. And not all limbs can be saved.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

item.title: Japanese Man Gambles Away a Town’s Covid Funds
item.description: An official in the rural Japanese town wired the 24-year-old man nearly $360,000 by mistake. He lost it in online casinos. Now, the town is suing and he has been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Kyodo News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Abu, Japan, is about 100 miles north of the nearest major city, Fukuoka, in an area of Yamaguchi Prefecture where agriculture, fishing and forestry drive the economy.

item.title: Around Kharkiv, Ukrainians Emerge to Find Lives in Ruin
item.description: After sheltering underground since February, residents of the beseiged city have finally been able to to assess the damage the Russians left behind. The discoveries have been grisly.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: The wreckage of a market that was bombed in the Saltivka neighborhood in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.

item.title: Economic Headwinds Mount as Leaders Weigh Costs of Confronting Russia
item.description: Top economic officials are gathering this week to discuss how to keep pressure on Vladimir V. Putin without sinking their economies.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine arrived in Przemsyl, Poland, in March. The conflict is taking an economic toll on Poland, which has absorbed more than three million refugees.

item.title: Strongmen in Turkey and Hungary Stall Unity in NATO and the E.U.
item.description: Russia benefits as Turkey slows down Swedish and Finnish applications to NATO and Hungary continues to block an E.U. embargo on Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.

item.title: Stop Picking Endangered Phallic Plant, Cambodia Warns
item.description: In Cambodia, video of women suggestively joking around with a protected carnivorous specimen prompted a government admonition: Hands off, people.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:credit: Luisa Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: The Nepenthes gracilis, a carnivorous plant, at an exhibition in Colombia in 2018. The Nepenthes genus is distinctive for an elongated receptacle, a pitcher, with a lid that closes and trap insects inside.

item.title: In Bucha, a Symbol of Death and Atrocity, Life Returns
item.description: About 10,000 residents have come back to this eastern Ukrainian city, which is racing to repair the physical and psychological damage from Russia’s occupation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A couple in Bucha, Ukraine, last Wednesday. The city outside of Kyiv has been working hard to clear debris from the Russian occupation.

item.title: U.K. Lawmaker Reportedly Arrested Over Rape Allegations
item.description: The arrest, of a man who has not yet been identified, was the latest in a string of sexual misconduct allegations against members of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The reported arrest of a British lawmaker comes on the heels of a number of troubling incidents in Parliament.

item.title: With Gas Pumps All but Dry, Sri Lanka Faces Its ‘Most Difficult Time’
item.description: The island nation’s new prime minister revealed that the country’s economic disaster was even worse than imagined.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for fuel in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday.

item.title: Coping With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: Our correspondent takes you inside Shanghai’s Covid lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Jacqueline Wong/Reuters
item.media:description: Covid testing at a residential compound in Shanghai yesterday.

item.title: U.S. Eyeing Russian Energy Sanctions Over Ukraine War, Officials Say
item.description: The revenue powers Vladimir V. Putin’s war machine in Ukraine. But plans for new U.S. sanctions could create problems with China, India and other major buyers.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gazprom Neft’s oil refinery in Moscow. New restrictions on Russian energy sales have greater potential for long-term damage to the country’s economy.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Turkey’s efforts to delay Finland’s and Sweden’s NATO applications.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Adem Altan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.

item.title: Russia Uses Surrender in Mariupol to Portray Ukrainians as Terrorists
item.description: Many soldiers who surrendered from Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant belong to the Azov battalion, a group with far-right roots, and the Kremlin may now put them on trial just as Ukraine is prosecuting Russians for war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo taken during a trip organized by the Russian Ministry of Defense shows Russian soldiers in a destroyed part of a Mariupol factory on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Turkey’s NATO Block
item.description: Plus North Korea’s Covid strategy and China’s expanding internet censorship.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Circus
item.media:credit: Johanna Geron/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Finland and Sweden submitted their NATO applications on Wednesday morning.

item.title: The World Is as Vulnerable as Ever to Pandemics, an Expert Panel Concludes
item.description: The authors of the new report zeroed in on the uneven distribution of vaccines around the world as one of the major hurdles to overcome.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers giving a coronavirus vaccine at a home in Colombo, Sri Lanka, in March.

item.title: Biden Endorses Finland and Sweden’s Bids to Join NATO
item.description: Mr. Biden’s pledge is far short of a treaty, or even an executive agreement committing the United States to come to the aid of both countries.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden timed his statement to precede a visit to the White House on Thursday by Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson of Sweden and President Sauli Niinisto of Finland.

item.title: Russian Soldier Pleads Guilty in Kyiv to Violating ‘Laws and Customs of War’
item.description: Sgt. Vadim Shyshimarin, 21, admitted in a Ukrainian court he had fatally shot a 62-year-old man on a bicycle in the village in the Sumy region in the early days of the invasion. He faces 10 years to life in prison.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Efrem Lukatsky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin, 21, at a court hearing in Kyiv on Wednesday. He pleaded guilty to shooting a man in the Sumy region of Ukraine early in the war.

item.title: John Fetterman: ‘Unfussy and Plain-Spoken’
item.description: John Fetterman, the Democratic Senate nominee in Pennsylvania, isn’t like most politicians in his party.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Fetterman in Pennsylvania this month.

item.title: Do Airline Offset Programs Really Reduce Your Carbon Footprint?
item.description: Carbon credits could eventually play an important role in fighting climate change, but right now a few dollars’ worth won’t change much.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:credit: Keith Morris/Alamy
item.media:description: Offsets seek to compensate for greenhouse gas emissions in one place by funding emissions reductions or carbon removal somewhere else.

item.title: ‘I could not stay away’: With Russians pushed back, residents return to Kharkiv.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daryna Mostyvskaya hugging her mother, Lyudmyla Mostyvskaya, who returned to Kharkiv, Ukraine, by train on Tuesday.

item.title: Labour asks if Conservatives broke U.K. election laws by accepting a donation linked to a Russian account.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: David M. Benett/Getty Images for Halcyon Art International
item.media:description: Ehud Sheleg, second left, at the 2019 Venice Biennale.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The surrender of Ukrainian forces in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Alexei Alexandrov/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers, who had held out for weeks at the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol, were evacuated on Tuesday. They are now in Russian custody and their futures are unclear.

item.title: Ukrainian Holdouts in Mariupol Surrender to an Uncertain Fate
item.description: The government’s order for hundreds of remaining fighters to stand down offers Russia a propaganda victory, but prospects for a prisoner swap seem unclear at best.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Rick Gladstone
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Alexei Alexandrov/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen in a bus after they were evacuated from Mariupol’s besieged Azovstal steel plant on Tuesday. They are now in Russian custody and their futures are unclear.

item.title: Russian Hacking Cartel Attacks Costa Rican Government Agencies
item.description: Experts who track the hackers’ actions said the group had recently begun to shift its focus to countries in Central and South America, perhaps as retaliation against nations that have supported Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Mayela Lopez/Reuters
item.media:description: Hackers claiming to be affiliated with Conti broke into Costa Rica’s Ministry of Finance, the government said, and from there the ransomware spread to other agencies.

item.title: Biden Administration Offers Venezuela Minor Sanctions Relief
item.description: The Biden administration said it would relax restrictions on Chevron’s dealings with President Nicolás Maduro and remove sanctions from his relative.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Ariana Cubillos/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela during a May Day rally in Caracas, this month.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Sri Lanka, Out of Fuel
item.description: Plus lockdowns continue in Shanghai, and India’s community health workers press for a raise.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for fuel in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday.

item.title: Europe Rethinks Its Reliance on Burning Wood for Electricity
item.description: A new proposal would significantly rewrite E.U. rules on renewable energy, ending subsidies for biomass like wood pellets.
item.dc:creator: Lois Parshley
item.media:credit: Miguel Riopa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A biomass power plant in Pontevedra, Spain.

item.title: Hezbollah Loses Majority Bloc in Lebanon Election, Results Show
item.description: Voters drove out vital parliamentary allies of the militant faction, though not Hezbollah candidates themselves. A dozen new independents won seats.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Mahmoud Zayyat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Hezbollah banner in the southern city of Nabatiyeh, Lebanon, on Sunday during the national parliamentary elections.

item.title: Pentagon Faults Review of Deadly Airstrike but Finds No Wrongdoing
item.description: The military’s inquiry followed a New York Times investigation describing allegations that officials sought to conceal dozens of civilian casualties.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Dave Philipps
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Giuseppe Cacace/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People fleeing in Baghuz, Syria, in 2019. A Pentagon inquiry into a U.S. airstrike that killed dozens of people determined that most of those killed were probably Islamic State fighters.

item.title: Spain Considers Bill to Give Paid Period Leave to Women
item.description: A draft law would allow women to stay home if they are diagnosed by a doctor. It would also extend abortion access, but it faces an arduous path through Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Paul White/Associated Press
item.media:description: Madrid on Tuesday. Spain could become the first European country to give women paid time off for severe period pain.

item.title: With Ukraine Taking Firmer Stance, Peace Talks Grind to a Halt
item.description: The impasse is mainly driven by Russia’s insistence on controlling large areas of Ukrainian territory. But Ukraine is also emboldened by successes on the battlefield and angry over Russian atrocities.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surveying the damage in Malotaranivka, in the Donbas region of Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Finland and Sweden Say They Will Apply to Join NATO
item.description: They also said they would travel to Washington to meet with President Biden about the war in Ukraine and their bid to join the Western military alliance.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Sauli Niinisto of Finland, left, and King Carl Gustaf of Sweden in Stockholm on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Eurovision winners don’t regret flouting the rules with a plea for Mariupol.
item.description: The winning band’s lead singer said he still feared for the fighters who had been holed up beneath the Azovstal steel plant.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kalush Orchestra, the winners of the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest, in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Queen Makes Surprise Visit to Paddington Station in London
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II made a rare public appearance to celebrate the opening of the Elizabeth line in London, which is named in her honor.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Matthews/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II met workers who helped build a new train line, which runs west to east underneath central London.

item.title: Retired Russian Colonel Says on State TV That Ukraine War Isn’t Going Well
item.description: It was a rare moment in a country where broadcasters generally follow the Kremlin’s talking points about the war.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank in Malaya Rohan, a village outside Kharkiv that was occupied by the Russians, on Tuesday.

item.title: Poor Countries Face a Mounting Catastrophe Fueled by Inflation and Debt
item.description: Russia’s war in Ukraine is combining with a global tightening of credit and an economic slowdown in China to sow misery in low- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Ruth Maclean, Salman Masood, Elif Ince, Flávia Milhorance, Muktita Suhartono and Brenda Kiven
item.media:credit: Tom Saater for The New York Times
item.media:description: A food market in Cameroon, where food inflation is causing hardship.

item.title: The Foot Soldiers in India’s Battle to Improve Public Health
item.description: Over a million female health workers treat India’s most at-risk women and children, for little pay and sometimes at the cost of their own lives.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bhanwar Bai Jadoun, 38, center, an accredited social healthcare activist, and Anita Chowdhary, right, an auxiliary nurse midwife, weigh a newborn baby in Bagdoli, India, in February.

item.title: Shanghai Declares Victory in Covid Outbreak, but Lockdowns Continue
item.description: Reports in state news media about the return of daily life in the financial hub brought distressed responses from residents.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Alex Plavevski/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Officials declared that Shaghai had achieved “societal zero,” a term used by the Chinese authorities to indicate no uncontrolled community transmission.

item.title: In Risky Move, U.K. Says It May Scrap Northern Ireland Trade Rules
item.description: The decision sets Britain on a collision course with the European Union, 18 months after a trade deal that was meant to have completed Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters

item.title: North Korea’s Covid Outbreak Continues to Worsen
item.description: According to state media, nearly 1.5 million people have presented with a fever, and 56 have died, in what the country claimed was its first outbreak of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Kyodo, via Reuters
item.media:description: A worker disinfected a dining room at a sanitation-supplies factory in Pyongyang on Monday.

item.title: How do Ukrainians See the Western Response to the War?
item.description: Our reporters are answering readers’ questions about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Many of you have asked about sentiments in Ukraine about the West.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: People receiving humanitarian aid supplies in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv on Thursday.

item.title: Most Extremist Violence in the U.S. Comes From the Political Right
item.description: The Buffalo killings are part of a pattern: Most extremist violence in the U.S. comes from the political right.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the Buffalo shooting victims.

item.title: Prince Charles and Camilla Visit Canada
item.description: Prince Charles will make a three day tour of the country, where polls suggest there’s little support for the monarchy — but amending Canada’s Constitution is difficult.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Hannah Mckay
item.media:description: Prince Charles visiting Canada House in London last week.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: An apparent Russian victory in Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: The Azovstal steel complex in the southern port city of Mariupol on Sunday.

item.title: Michael Bloomberg Plans a $242 Million Investment in Clean Energy
item.description: The billionaire and former mayor of New York City will fund programs in 10 developing countries.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-fired power station in Metsimaholo, South Africa, about 65 miles south of Johannesburg. The country is one of 10 targeted in Michael R. Bloomberg’s initiative.

item.title: Biden Administration Lifting Some Trump-Era Restrictions on Cuba
item.description: The changes include an expansion of flights to the country and the restarting of a family reunification program.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Carlos Batista/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A traveler at the airport in Havana in March. The Biden administration has relaxed some restrictions after a lengthy review of Cuba policy.

item.title: Ukraine Signals End of Bitter Battle at Azovstal Steel Plant
item.description: More than 250 fighters were evacuated from the besieged Azovstal complex after holding out and sheltering civilians for weeks under near-constant Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: A wounded Ukrainian service member from the besieged Azovstal steel factory in Mariupol is transported under the escort of the pro-Russian military in Novoazovsk on Monday.

item.title: Further Russian Retreat Seen in East Ukraine, Another Setback for Putin
item.description: Russia appeared to shrink its already narrowed goals to take the Donbas region, as NATO and its two newest applicants, Sweden and Finland, practiced war games near Russia’s border.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Anton Troianovski, Rick Gladstone and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A complex in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday, that was damaged by Russian bombardment.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia’s Faltering Campaign
item.description: Plus climate’s role in Australia’s upcoming election and a Covid-19 protest at Peking University.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Johnson’s Softer Tone on Northern Ireland Trade Rules Belies Hard-Line Plans
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who traveled to Northern Ireland on Monday, also urged a power-sharing government in the wake of Sinn Fein’s victory in legislative elections.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Liam Mcburney
item.media:description: Mr. Johnson is also facing pressure from the Biden administration, which has warned him not to take any steps that could jeopardize the Good Friday Agreement.

item.title: Russia Planned a Major Military Overhaul. Ukraine Shows the Result.
item.description: Russia wanted to build a leaner, more flexible fighting force and eliminate waste, bureaucracy and corruption. But entrenched, Soviet-era practices endure.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Justyna Mielnikiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian soldier on an armored vehicle in the Georgian town of Igoeti in 2008.
